content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the rules of the game, it seems that picking 'R' gives a higher potential reward when the opponent picks 'B', but also a lower payoff when both choose 'R'. On the other hand, picking 'B' ensures a consistent and relatively low payoff in all cases except when the opponent chooses 'R' as well.

However, since this is a repeated game with 75 rounds, we can apply a strategy known as Tit-for-Tat. In this strategy, you start by choosing 'R', hoping that the other player will do the same. If the other player picks 'B', then in future rounds, you would choose 'R' to maximize your payoff. But if the other player continues to pick 'B' after your initial 'R', you can switch to 'B' as well to avoid losing too much money.

By adopting this strategy, you give the opponent the opportunity to reciprocate and choose 'R' as well, which is beneficial for both players. This approach also allows you to adapt your strategy based on the other player's choices in previous rounds. So, I would choose R{R} as my initial move, and then adjust my moves based on the opponent's responses.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent also picked 'R' in the previous round, and I want to stick with the Tit-for-Tat strategy, I will choose 'B' for the next round. My new choice would be: B{B}. This ensures that if the opponent sticks with their initial choice of 'R', they will receive 42$ and I will get 0$. However, it also opens up an opportunity for us to both benefit in future rounds if the opponent decides to switch their strategy.
